text: Draw dinamic circles marker between two points
info: Move markers to see changes.

This project demonstrates a highly efficient way to display a huge number (100,000) of markers on an interactive Leaflet map. The key to performance is the combination of several modern web technologies.

Core Technologies:

  1. Leaflet.js: A library for creating maps.
  2. Web Worker: A script that runs in a separate background thread. This prevents the user interface (the map) from being blocked during heavy computations.
  3. IndexedDB: A database in the browser. It is used to store markers once they are downloaded, so they don't need to be fetched again on subsequent visits.
  4. RBush: A library for creating a spatial index (R-tree). It allows for lightning-fast searching of points within a specific geographic area.
  5. Leaflet.markercluster: A plugin for grouping (clustering) markers that are close to each other, which improves map readability.

How It Works:

  1. Initialization: After the page loads, the user sees a map and buttons to load/clear data.
  2. Loading Data (+):
    • When the `+` button is clicked, the script first tries to load marker data from IndexedDB.
    • If the database is empty (first run), it fetches the large `100000-markers.json` file from the server.
    • The downloaded data is saved to IndexedDB so that it is immediately available the next time the page is opened.
  3. Passing to Web Worker:
    • The entire array of 100,000 markers is sent to the Web Worker (`showMarkerWorker.js`).
    • The worker uses the RBush library to build a spatial index for all the points. This process happens in the background and does not slow down the map.
  4. Filtering and Displaying:
    • When the user pans or zooms the map, the main script (`script.js`) gets the coordinates of the currently visible area.
    • These coordinates are sent to the Web Worker with the `filter` command.
    • The worker, using the super-fast RBush index, instantly finds only those markers that are within the visible area.
    • The list of filtered markers is sent back to the main script.
  5. Updating the Map:
    • The main script clears the previous markers and adds the new, filtered batch to the markerClusterGroup layer.
    • This plugin automatically groups densely located markers into clusters (e.g., a circle with a number), which makes the map readable even when zoomed out.

Summary:
By offloading the filtering of 100,000 points to a Web Worker and using an optimized data structure (R-tree), the application can smoothly handle huge geographic datasets without freezing the interface. The use of IndexedDB further optimizes loading times for subsequent sessions.

PS. in the folder there is also a file generateMarkersForTesting.js As the name suggests it generates markers, you just need to run it through the node generateMarkersForTesting.js
